main event: On June 9, 1955, in Warner Springs, California, there was a ground-visual observation of a large, silver, elliptical object that appeared to be floating at a constant altitude for 12 minutes. The object exhibited a gradual buildup of speed and then a leveling off, possibly resembling a balloon.
interesting points: The object was described as large, silver, and elliptical in shape, exhibiting a gradual change in speed over the course of 12 minutes.
The sighting seemed to bear the characteristics of a balloon, possibly due to the very light winds aloft at the time and the elongating and shortening appearance of the object.
The report mentions the object as resembling the moon enlarging and shrinking in appearance, moving south-west, and appearing very high.
Only one object was observed during this sighting, and it appeared to be very high in the sky.
The report offers various conclusions, including 'possibly aircraft,' 'possibly astronomical,' 'probably astronomical,' 'insufficient data for evaluation,' and 'unknown.'
